awd_titl_txt: Studying Jupiter's magnetospheric response to Io's volcanic activity
awd_abstract_narration:
Jupiter's innermost satellite, Io, is the most volcanic body in the solar system.  Volcanic activity on Io helps to maintain a tenuous atmosphere that consists of neutral and ionized gas. The ionized component of Io's atmosphere interacts strongly with Jupiter's powerful magnetic field. This interaction causes some of the gas from Io's atmosphere to be transferred to Jupiter's magnetosphere.  This research project will study how the volcanic output of Io affects Jupiter's magnetosphere.  Results from the study will shed light on the physical processes that control mass transfer between planets and their satellites; and on planetary magnetospheres in general.  The project will also support a teacher training workshop that broadens participation in science by reaching elementary and middle school science teachers in low-income and underrepresented communities.

This research project will study variations in Io's volcanic output to identify the mechanisms that drive radial transport in Jupiter's magnetosphere.  The research team will use a 35-cm robotically controlled telescope equipped with a coronagraph to record images of sulfur-ion emission in the Io plasma torus (IPT) every fifteen minutes for several months a year for five years.  They will use the same telescope to record coronagraphic images of the Jovian sodium nebula, which is a proxy for Io's volcanic activity.  In addition, they will use the Infrared Red Telescope Facility to periodically conduct infrared observations of the Jovian sodium nebula, which are a more direct proxy of volcanic activity.  The high quality, high temporal resolution, and long duration of the observations would maximize the chance of recording a response of Jupiter's magnetosphere to a large volcanic outburst on Io.  By measuring the temporal relationships between Io's volcanic activity and the IPT, as well as the IPT's overall brightness and east-west extent, the team will be able to distinguish between the two main mechanisms that are thought to drive mass loading and radial transport in Jupiter's magnetosphere.  The project will also provide new content on Io's volcanism and Jupiter's magnetism to a teacher training workshop.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Jupiter, like Earth, has a magnetic field that combines with ionized material to create the environment around the planet known as its magnetosphere.  A planetary magnetosphere is distinct from the mix of magnetic field and ions that come from the sun, called the solar wind.  Unlike Earth's magnetosphere, which receives a small amount of mass that leaks in from the solar wind, Jupiter receives a large amount of mass (1,000 kg/s) from its highly volcanic moon, Io.  In both cases, the mass diffuses back out to rejoin the solar wind, however, in the case of Jupiter, many more physical processes are detectable due to the large amount of material involved.  Thus, by studying Jupiter's magnetosphere, we can learn about magnetospheric processes that are otherwise difficult or impossible to detect at the Earth.  The process we concentrated on for this project was radial diffusion -- the motion of material from its source at Io to the outer reaches of Jupiter's magnetosphere, where the material leaves and joins the solar wind.
To achieve our goal, we constructed the Io Input/Output observatory (IoIO), composed almost entirely of off-the-shelf parts popular with amateur astronomers (Figure 1) to study two gasses that trace their origins from Io.  Neutral sodium forms the Jovian sodium nebula (Figure 2) and singly ionized sulfur collects into a ring-like structure known as the Io plasma torus (IPT; Figure 3).  We then used IoIO to monitor the brightnesses of the sodium nebula and IPT over a 6-year period (Figure 4) as well as the position of the IPT.  The IPT brightness is compared to its position for the first three years of the study in Figure 5.
Our study resulted in several new discoveries, the exploration of which are still ongoing.  The first discovery was unexpected and available from a very simple interpretation of Figure 4.  The plots show 1-- 2 brightness enhancements sodium and IPT each 7-month observing period.  By noting that the average brightnesses of the emissions are set by the enhancements, not any quiescent level, we are able to challenge the current scientific paradigm, that holds the material leaving Io comes primarily from the direct change from solid to gas (sublimation) of frosts on Io's surface, a process that is fairly stable over time.  Instead, we see that the majority of the material leaving Io's atmosphere comes primarily from the processes that drive the enhancements in the sodium nebula and IPT emission -- likely some sort of volcanism.
Another important discovery, related to the original science goal of our project, is seen by comparing the trends in the top and bottom panels of Figure 5.  Previous observational studies suggested that the trends in the IPT brightness and positions should be related -- the black dots in the top panel and blue dots in the bottom panel should show similar trends in time, perhaps with a slight delay -- because events in the outer magnetosphere were thought to trigger diffusion in the IPT (the "outside in" hypothesis).  Theoretical studies, on the other hand, suggested that physical processes within the IPT itself trigger radial diffusion (the "inside out" hypothesis).  The IoIO data provides observational evidence in support of the "inside out" hypothesis.
Finally, our project has broader impacts beyond our science theme in two major ways: (1) We expended PSI's existing Workshops in Science Education and Resources "Volcanoes of the Solar System" to include information on volcanoes on Io and offered several workshops each year, with accommodations through remote options during the COVID pandemic.  (2) We modified the software that controls IoIO to enable it to become PSI's general use observatory and conducted several pilot studies, one of which was funded by NASA's Exoplanets Research Program: "Finding the Next Doomed Worlds." This project looks for evidence of extra-solar planets spiraling into their host stars.  IoIO has also recorded dramatic images of Mercury's sodium tail, which looks like a comet, as well recording images of the bright comet NEOWISE in sodium (Figure 6).  Many of IoIO's images and results have been featured in widely circulated press releases, inspiring amateur astronomers to record similar images.  We are very grateful for the support NSF has provided for this project and the resulting impact it has had both inside and outside of our field of research.


Last Modified: 11/02/2023
Modified by: Jeffrey P Morgenthaler

Images (1 of )
  • The Planetary Science Institute's Io Input/Output Observatory (IoIO) is composed almost entirely of off-the-shelf parts popular with amateur astronomers. It is outfitted with special filters and a coronagraph (long tube to the right) that allow it to image faint gases near Jupiter.
    Jeffrey P. Morgenthaler
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey P Morgenthaler
    IoIO
  • IoIO image of neutral sodium emission around Jupiter forms the Jovian sodium nebula. Jupiter's moon Io is ultimately the source of the sodium.
    Jeffrey P. Morgenthaler
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey P Morgenthaler
    IoIO image of Jovian sodium nebula
  • Ionized sulfur that traces its origin to Jupiter's moon Io collects into an ethereal hula-hoop, seen edge on in this view captured by IoIO.
    Jeffrey P. Morgenthaler
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey P Morgenthaler
    IoIO image of the Io plasma torus (IPT)
  • The time sequence (X-axis) of the sodium nebula at three distances from Jupiter (top Y-axis) and IPT on each side of Jupiter (bottom Y-axis). Enhancements are common and long-lasting, providing insights into the mechanisms that dominate the release of material from Io's atmosphere.
    Jeffrey P. Morgenthaler
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey P Morgenthaler
    Time sequence of Jovian sodium nebula and IPT brightnesses
  • The time sequence (X-axis) of IPT brightnesses on the east and west sides (top Y-axis) and average shift of IPT toward the east (bottom Y-axis). The IPT eastward shift provides insights into the flow of material into and out of Jupiter's broader magnetosphere.
    Jeffrey P. Morgenthaler
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey P Morgenthaler
    IPT east and west brightnesses and IPT average position
  • Two views of comet 2020 F3 (NEOWISE) captured by IoIO. Left: scattered sunlight from cometary dust -- the primary emission seen by the naked eye. Right: emission from sodium, which likely derives its origin from NaCl in the comet.
    Jeffrey P. Morgenthaler and Carl Schmidt
    Copyrighted
    Jeffrey P Morgenthaler
    Comet 2020 F3 (NEOWISE) in two wavelengths bands: dust and sodium
